{{Infobox military structure |name=Camp Thunderbolt |partof= |location= |coordinates={{Coord|13.76|N|109.10|E|display=inline|name=Camp Thunderbolt}} |image= |caption= |type= |code= |built= 1965 |builder= |materials= |height= |used= 1965-present |demolished= |condition= |ownership= |controlledby= |garrison= |commanders= |occupants= [[Capital Mechanized Infantry Division (Republic of Korea)|Capital Division]] |battles= [[File:Vietnam Service Ribbon.svg|60px]]
[[Vietnam War]] |events= }} {{Infobox airport | name = ROK Strip Airfield | elevation-f = 60 | elevation-m = | website = | metric-rwy = | r1-number = | r1-length-f = 3000 | r1-length-m = | r1-surface = [[Marsden Matting|PSP]] | footnotes = }} '''Camp Thunderbolt''' (also known as '''ROK Strip Airfield''' or '''ROK Valley''') is a former [[Republic of Korea Army]] (ROKA) base west of [[Qui Nhơn]] in [[Bình Định Province]], [[Vietnam]]. ==History== The base was originally established in late 1965 by the [[70th Engineer Battalion]]{{cite book|last=Traas|first=Adrian|title=Engineers at War|publisher=Government Printing Office|year=|isbn=9780160882739|page=34}} approximately 14 km west of Qui Nhơn, 5 km south of [[Lane Army Airfield]] and southwest of the [[National Route 19 (Vietnam)|Highway 19]] and [[National Route 1A (Vietnam)|Highway 1]] intersection.{{cite book|last=Kelley|first=Michael|title=Where we were in Vietnam|publisher=Hellgate Press|year=2002|isbn=978-1555716257|pages=5–350}} Further improvements to the base were made by the [[19th Engineer Battalion]].{{rp|34–5}} The Camp served as the base for the [[Capital Mechanized Infantry Division (Republic of Korea)|Capital Mechanized Infantry Division]] (also known as the '''Tiger Division''') from their arrival in Vietnam in September 1965 until their departure in March 1973. On 5 March 1971 [[Boeing CH-47 Chinook|CH-47C]] #67-18518 of the [[180th Assault Support Helicopter Company]] on approach to Lane Army Airfield collided with a ROKA [[Cessna O-1 Bird Dog|O-1D]] causing both aircraft to crash killing 5 passengers and crew on the CH-47 and the pilot of the O-1.{{cite web|url=http://www.virtualwall.org/ds/StrawBM01a.htm|title=Barry Mercer Straw|publisher=Virtual Wall|accessdate=11 November 2014}} ==Current use== The base appears to remain in use by the [[People's Army of Vietnam]]. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Military bases of the Vietnam War]] {{VietnamWar-stub}}
